rev.diff:
Line 64: Line 64:
==Reception==
==Reception==
â
In the opinion of [[Engaget]] editor Darren Murph, the Galaxy Nexus was "smooth as ever. Without question, this is easily the slickest, most polished version of Android yet"<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/19/google-ice-cream-sandwich-android-4-0-a-hands-on-screenshot-g/</ref> and that it "carries on the Nexus torch in spectacular fashion", "The 1.2GHz dual-core processor was startlingly fast", "the panel looks downright gorgeous, with unbeatable viewing angles, remarkably crisp text and graphics and a beautiful feel as one swipes across it" and "We found in our play time that ICS was amazingly responsive in every aspect. Swiping was a breeze. Gestures worked beautifully. The entire experience just felt polished. In a way, it's as if Android's growing a bit and maturing before our eyes".<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsung-galaxy-nexus-hands-on/</ref>
+
In the opinion of [[Engaget]] editor Darren Murph, the Galaxy Nexus was "smooth as ever. Without question, this is easily the slickest, most polished version of Android yet"<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/19/google-ice-cream-sandwich-android-4-0-a-hands-on-screenshot-g/</ref> and that it "carries on the Nexus torch in spectacular fashion", "The 1.2GHz dual-core processor was startlingly fast", "the panel looks downright gorgeous, with unbeatable viewing angles, remarkably crisp text and graphics and a beautiful feel as one swipes across it" and "We found in our play time that [[Android version history#4.x Ice Cream Sandwich|ICS]] was amazingly responsive in every aspect. Swiping was a breeze. Gestures worked beautifully. The entire experience just felt polished. In a way, it's as if Android's growing a bit and maturing before our eyes".<ref>http://www.engadget.com/2011/10/18/samsung-galaxy-nexus-hands-on/</ref>
